segment.source: Draw shapes
segment.target: Draw shapes

segment.source: Learn how to draw shapes, such as ellipses, rectangles, polygons, and paths.
segment.target: Learn how to draw shapes, such as ellipses, rectangles, polygons, and paths.

segment.source: The Path class is the way to visualize a fairly complex vector-based drawing language in a XAML UI; for example, you can draw Bezier curves.
segment.target: The Path class is the way to visualize a fairly complex vector-based drawing language in a XAML UI; for example, you can draw Bezier curves.

segment.target: Draw shapes

segment.target: Path

segment.source: Windows.UI.Xaml.Shapes namespace
segment.target: Windows.UI.Xaml.Shapes namespace

segment.source: Windows.UI.Xaml.Media namespace
segment.target: Windows.UI.Xaml.Media namespace

segment.source: Learn how to draw shapes, such as ellipses, rectangles, polygons, and paths.
segment.target: Learn how to draw shapes, such as ellipses, rectangles, polygons, and paths.

segment.source: The Path class is the way to visualize a fairly complex vector-based drawing language in a XAML UI; for example, you can draw Bezier curves.
segment.target: The Path class is the way to visualize a fairly complex vector-based drawing language in a XAML UI; for example, you can draw Bezier curves.

segment.source: Introduction
segment.target: Introduction

segment.source: Two sets of classes define a region of space in XAML UI: Shape classes and Geometry classes.
segment.target: Two sets of classes define a region of space in XAML UI: Shape classes and Geometry classes.

segment.source: The main difference between these classes is that a Shape has a brush associated with it and can be rendered to the screen, and a Geometry simply defines a region of space and is not rendered unless it helps contribute information to another UI property.
segment.target: The main difference between these classes is that a Shape has a brush associated with it and can be rendered to the screen, and a Geometry simply defines a region of space and is not rendered unless it helps contribute information to another UI property.

segment.source: You can think of a Shape as a UIElement with its boundary defined by a Geometry.
segment.target: You can think of a Shape as a UIElement with its boundary defined by a Geometry.

segment.source: This topic covers mainly the Shape classes.
segment.target: This topic covers mainly the Shape classes.

segment.source: The Shape classes are Line, Ellipse, Rectangle, Polygon, Polyline, and Path.
segment.target: The Shape classes are Line, Ellipse, Rectangle, Polygon, Polyline, and Path.

segment.source: Path is interesting because it can define an arbitrary geometry, and the Geometry class is involved here because that's one way to define the parts of a Path.
segment.target: Path is interesting because it can define an arbitrary geometry, and the Geometry class is involved here because that's one way to define the parts of a Path.

segment.source: Fill and Stroke for shapes
segment.target: Fill and Stroke for shapes

segment.source: For a Shape to render to the app canvas, you must associate a Brush with it.
segment.target: For a Shape to render to the app canvas, you must associate a Brush with it.

segment.source: Set the Fill property of the Shape to the Brush you want.
segment.target: Set the Fill property of the Shape to the Brush you want.

segment.source: For more info about brushes, see Using brushes.
segment.target: For more info about brushes, see Using brushes.

segment.source: A Shape can also have a Stroke, which is a line that is drawn around the shape's perimeter.
segment.target: A Shape can also have a Stroke, which is a line that is drawn around the shape's perimeter.

segment.source: A Stroke also requires a Brush that defines its appearance, and should have a non-zero value for StrokeThickness.
segment.target: A Stroke also requires a Brush that defines its appearance, and should have a non-zero value for StrokeThickness.

segment.source: StrokeThickness is a property that defines the perimeter's thickness around the shape edge.
segment.target: StrokeThickness is a property that defines the perimeter's thickness around the shape edge.

segment.source: If you don't specify a Brush value for Stroke, or if you set StrokeThickness to 0, then the border around the shape is not drawn.
segment.target: If you don't specify a Brush value for Stroke, or if you set StrokeThickness to 0, then the border around the shape is not drawn.

segment.source: Ellipse
segment.target: Ellipse

segment.source: An Ellipse is a shape with a curved perimeter.
segment.target: An Ellipse is a shape with a curved perimeter.

segment.source: To create a basic Ellipse, specify a Width, Height, and a Brush for the Fill.
segment.target: To create a basic Ellipse, specify a Width, Height, and a Brush for the Fill.

segment.source: The next example creates an Ellipse with a Width of 200 and a Height of 200, and uses a SteelBlue colored SolidColorBrush as its Fill.
segment.target: The next example creates an Ellipse with a Width of 200 and a Height of 200, and uses a SteelBlue colored SolidColorBrush as its Fill.

segment.source: Here's the rendered Ellipse.
segment.target: Here's the rendered Ellipse.

segment.source: A rendered Ellipse.
segment.target: A rendered Ellipse.

segment.source: In this case the Ellipse is what most people would consider a circle, but that's how you declare a circle shape in XAML: use an Ellipse with equal Width and Height.
segment.target: In this case the Ellipse is what most people would consider a circle, but that's how you declare a circle shape in XAML: use an Ellipse with equal Width and Height.

segment.source: When an Ellipse is positioned in a UI layout, its size is assumed to be the same as a rectangle with that Width and Height; the area outside the perimeter does not have rendering but still is part of its layout slot size.
segment.target: When an Ellipse is positioned in a UI layout, its size is assumed to be the same as a rectangle with that Width and Height; the area outside the perimeter does not have rendering but still is part of its layout slot size.

segment.source: A set of 6 Ellipse elements are part of the control template for the ProgressRing control, and 2 concentric Ellipse elements are part of a RadioButton.
segment.target: A set of 6 Ellipse elements are part of the control template for the ProgressRing control, and 2 concentric Ellipse elements are part of a RadioButton.

segment.source: Rectangle
segment.target: Rectangle

segment.source: A Rectangle is a four-sided shape with its opposite sides being equal.
segment.target: A Rectangle is a four-sided shape with its opposite sides being equal.

segment.source: To create a basic Rectangle, specify a Width, a Height, and a Fill.
segment.target: To create a basic Rectangle, specify a Width, a Height, and a Fill.

segment.source: You can round the corners of a Rectangle.
segment.target: You can round the corners of a Rectangle.

segment.source: To create rounded corners, specify a value for the RadiusX and RadiusY properties.
segment.target: To create rounded corners, specify a value for the RadiusX and RadiusY properties.

segment.source: These properties specify the x-axis and y-axis of an ellipse that defines the curve of the corners.
segment.target: These properties specify the x-axis and y-axis of an ellipse that defines the curve of the corners.

segment.source: The maximum allowed value of RadiusX is the Width divided by two and the maximum allowed value of RadiusY is the Height divided by two.
segment.target: The maximum allowed value of RadiusX is the Width divided by two and the maximum allowed value of RadiusY is the Height divided by two.

segment.source: The next example creates a Rectangle with a Width of 200 and a Height of 100.
segment.target: The next example creates a Rectangle with a Width of 200 and a Height of 100.

segment.source: It uses a Blue value of SolidColorBrush for its Fill and a Black value of SolidColorBrush for its Stroke.
segment.target: It uses a Blue value of SolidColorBrush for its Fill and a Black value of SolidColorBrush for its Stroke.

segment.source: We set the StrokeThickness to 3.
segment.target: We set the StrokeThickness to 3.

segment.source: We set the RadiusX property to 50 and the RadiusY property to 10, which gives the Rectangle rounded corners.
segment.target: We set the RadiusX property to 50 and the RadiusY property to 10, which gives the Rectangle rounded corners.

segment.source: Here's the rendered Polygon.
segment.target: Here's the rendered Polygon.

segment.source: A rendered Polygon.
segment.target: A rendered Polygon.

segment.source: Tip A Point value is often used as a type in XAML for scenarios other than declaring the vertices of shapes.
segment.target: Tip A Point value is often used as a type in XAML for scenarios other than declaring the vertices of shapes.

segment.source: For example, a Point is part of the event data for touch events, so you can know exactly where in a coordinate space the touch action occurred.
segment.target: For example, a Point is part of the event data for touch events, so you can know exactly where in a coordinate space the touch action occurred.

segment.source: For more info about Point and how to use it in XAML or code, see the API reference topic for Point.
segment.target: For more info about Point and how to use it in XAML or code, see the API reference topic for Point.

segment.source: Line
segment.target: Line

segment.source: A Line is simply a line drawn between two points in coordinate space.
segment.target: A Line is simply a line drawn between two points in coordinate space.

segment.source: A Line ignores any value provided for Fill, because it has no interior space.
segment.target: A Line ignores any value provided for Fill, because it has no interior space.

segment.source: For a Line, make sure to specify values for the Stroke and StrokeThickness properties, because otherwise the Line won't render.
segment.target: For a Line, make sure to specify values for the Stroke and StrokeThickness properties, because otherwise the Line won't render.

segment.source: You don't use Point values to specify a Line shape, instead you use discrete Double values for X1, Y1, X2 and Y2.
segment.target: You don't use Point values to specify a Line shape, instead you use discrete Double values for X1, Y1, X2 and Y2.

segment.source: This enables minimal markup for horizontal or vertical lines.
segment.target: This enables minimal markup for horizontal or vertical lines.

segment.source: For example, defines a horizontal line that is 400 pixels long.
segment.target: For example, defines a horizontal line that is 400 pixels long.

segment.source: The other X,Y properties are 0 by default, so in terms of points this XAML would draw a line from to .
segment.target: The other X,Y properties are 0 by default, so in terms of points this XAML would draw a line from to .

segment.source: You could then use a TranslateTransform to move the entire Line, if you wanted it to start at a point other than (0,0).
segment.target: You could then use a TranslateTransform to move the entire Line, if you wanted it to start at a point other than (0,0).

segment.source: Polyline
segment.target: Polyline

segment.source: A Polyline is similar to a Polygon in that the boundary of the shape is defined by a set of points, except the last point in a Polyline is not connected to the first point.
segment.target: A Polyline is similar to a Polygon in that the boundary of the shape is defined by a set of points, except the last point in a Polyline is not connected to the first point.

segment.source: Note You could explicitly have an identical start point and end point in the Points set for the Polyline, but in that case you probably could have used a Polygon instead.
segment.target: Note You could explicitly have an identical start point and end point in the Points set for the Polyline, but in that case you probably could have used a Polygon instead.

segment.source: If you specify a Fill of a Polyline, the Fill paints the interior space of the shape, even if the start point and end point of the Points set for the Polyline do not intersect.
segment.target: If you specify a Fill of a Polyline, the Fill paints the interior space of the shape, even if the start point and end point of the Points set for the Polyline do not intersect.

segment.source: If you do not specify a Fill, then the Polyline is similar to what would have rendered if you had specified several individual Line elements where the start points and end points of consecutive lines intersected.
segment.target: If you do not specify a Fill, then the Polyline is similar to what would have rendered if you had specified several individual Line elements where the start points and end points of consecutive lines intersected.

segment.source: As with a Polygon, the Points property defines the collection of points that make up the boundary.
segment.target: As with a Polygon, the Points property defines the collection of points that make up the boundary.

segment.source: In XAML, you define the points with a comma-separated list.
segment.target: In XAML, you define the points with a comma-separated list.

segment.source: In code-behind, you use a PointCollection to define the points and you add each individual point as a Point structure to the collection.
segment.target: In code-behind, you use a PointCollection to define the points and you add each individual point as a Point structure to the collection.

segment.source: This example creates a Polyline with four points set to , , , and .
segment.target: This example creates a Polyline with four points set to , , , and .

segment.source: A Stroke is defined but not a Fill.
segment.target: A Stroke is defined but not a Fill.

segment.source: Here's the rendered Polyline.
segment.target: Here's the rendered Polyline.

segment.source: Notice that the first and last points are not connected by the Stroke outline as they are in a Polygon.
segment.target: Notice that the first and last points are not connected by the Stroke outline as they are in a Polygon.

segment.source: A rendered Polyline.
segment.target: A rendered Polyline.

segment.source: Path
segment.target: Path

segment.source: A Path is the most versatile Shape because you can use it to define an arbitrary geometry.
segment.target: A Path is the most versatile Shape because you can use it to define an arbitrary geometry.

segment.source: But with this versatility comes complexity.
segment.target: But with this versatility comes complexity.

segment.source: Let's now look at how to create a basic Path in XAML.
segment.target: Let's now look at how to create a basic Path in XAML.

segment.source: You define the geometry of a path with the Data property.
segment.target: You define the geometry of a path with the Data property.

segment.source: There are two techniques for setting Data:
segment.target: There are two techniques for setting Data:

segment.source: You can set a string value for Data in XAML.
segment.target: You can set a string value for Data in XAML.

segment.source: In this form, the Path.Data value is consuming a serialization format for graphics.
segment.target: In this form, the Path.Data value is consuming a serialization format for graphics.

segment.source: You typically don't text-edit this value in string form after it is first established.
segment.target: You typically don't text-edit this value in string form after it is first established.

segment.source: Instead, you use design tools that enable you to work in a design or drawing metaphor on a surface.
segment.target: Instead, you use design tools that enable you to work in a design or drawing metaphor on a surface.

segment.source: Then you save or export the output, and this gives you a XAML file or XAML string fragment with Path.Data information.
segment.target: Then you save or export the output, and this gives you a XAML file or XAML string fragment with Path.Data information.

segment.source: You can set the Data property to a single Geometry object.
segment.target: You can set the Data property to a single Geometry object.

segment.source: This can be done in code or in XAML.
segment.target: This can be done in code or in XAML.

segment.source: That single Geometry is typically a GeometryGroup, which acts as a container that can composite multiple geometry definitions into a single object for purposes of the object model.
segment.target: That single Geometry is typically a GeometryGroup, which acts as a container that can composite multiple geometry definitions into a single object for purposes of the object model.

segment.source: The most common reason for doing this is because you want to use one or more of the curves and complex shapes that can be defined as Segments values for a PathFigure, for example BezierSegment.
segment.target: The most common reason for doing this is because you want to use one or more of the curves and complex shapes that can be defined as Segments values for a PathFigure, for example BezierSegment.

segment.source: This example shows a Path that might have resulted from using Blend for Visual Studio to produce just a few vector shapes and then saving the result as XAML.
segment.target: This example shows a Path that might have resulted from using Blend for Visual Studio to produce just a few vector shapes and then saving the result as XAML.

segment.source: The total Path consists of a Bezier curve segment and a line segment.
segment.target: The total Path consists of a Bezier curve segment and a line segment.

segment.source: The example is mainly intended to give you some examples of what elements exist in the Path.Data serialization format and what the numbers represent.
segment.target: The example is mainly intended to give you some examples of what elements exist in the Path.Data serialization format and what the numbers represent.

segment.source: This Data begins with the move command, indicated by "M", which establishes an absolute start point for the path.
segment.target: This Data begins with the move command, indicated by "M", which establishes an absolute start point for the path.

segment.source: The first segment is a cubic Bezier curve that begins at and ends at , which is drawn by using the two control points and .
segment.target: The first segment is a cubic Bezier curve that begins at and ends at , which is drawn by using the two control points and .

segment.source: This segment is indicated by the "C" command in the Data attribute string.
segment.target: This segment is indicated by the "C" command in the Data attribute string.

segment.source: The second segment begins with an absolute horizontal line command "H", which specifies a line drawn from the preceding subpath endpoint to a new endpoint .
segment.target: The second segment begins with an absolute horizontal line command "H", which specifies a line drawn from the preceding subpath endpoint to a new endpoint .

segment.source: Because it's a horizontal line command, the value specified is an x-coordinate.
segment.target: Because it's a horizontal line command, the value specified is an x-coordinate.

segment.source: One reason you might use PathGeometry with the various parts is that each of the parts has Double and Point properties that you potentially could target for a UI animation.
segment.target: One reason you might use PathGeometry with the various parts is that each of the parts has Double and Point properties that you potentially could target for a UI animation.

segment.source: You can't do that with the serialization form of Path.Data.
segment.target: You can't do that with the serialization form of Path.Data.

segment.source: For more info, see Storyboarded animations.
segment.target: For more info, see Storyboarded animations.
